purpleculture_pinyin:
jiǎ
cape (geography); headland
мыс (география); мыс
rtega_mnemonic:
岬岬RScape, promontory, headland
  • armoured 甲 piece of mountain 山 sticking out in the sea: cape or headland
purpleculture_info: Pictophonetic: 甲 indicates the sound; 山 (mountain) conveys the meaning.
purpleculture_examples:
岬角 [ jiǎ jiǎo ]: cape; headland; promontory
海岬 [ hǎi jiǎ ]: headland
地岬 [ dì jiǎ ]: cape (geography); headland
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿰ Left to right
    • 山 [ shān ] mountain, hill, peak
    • 甲 [ jiǎ ] armor, shell; fingernails; 1st heavenly stem
heisig_story: Like the cape (Frame 164) and the promontory (Frame 840), the headland refers to a jut of land. Its elements: mountain . . . roots.
koohiiStory1: A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!).
koohiiStory2: Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain).
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You see a mountain in the shape of a turtle shell sticking out into the ocean. It's a cape! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).
WaniKani_Reading_Info: The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the first (甲) mountain (山) is the headland

岬字的基本解释

岬
jiǎ
两山之间：山岬。
突入海中的陆地：岬角（突入海中陆地的尖端）。

岬字的汉语字典释义

[①]［jiǎ］
［《集韻》古狎切，入狎，見。］
(1)两山之间。也叫峡。
(2)见“岬角”。
(3)见“岬嵑”。

岬字的英文翻译

◎ 岬
cape, headland, promontory

岬字的康熙字典解释

【寅集中】【山字部】　岬； 康熙笔画：8； 页码：页309第23
【集韻】古狎切，音甲。山旁也。【淮南子·原道訓】徘徊於山岬之旁。【註】岬，山脅也。【左思·吳都賦】傾藪薄，倒岬岫。【註】兩山閒曰岬。　又赤岬，山名，在蜀夔州府城北，上有孤城，卽古魚復縣基，南連白帝山，不生草木，土石悉赤。俗云如人袒胛，故名赤岬。　又岬嵑，接連貌。【張協·洛禊賦】都人士女，奕奕祁祁。車駕岬嵑，充溢中逵。　【集韻】或作?。

岬字的源字形

字源演变：

小篆楷体

字形对比：

中国大陆宋体台湾细明体香港明体日本明朝体韩国明朝体旧字形
岬字的起名意思

指突入海中的陆地。

cape
Basic explanation of words
cape
jiǎ
Between the two mountains: the cape.
Land protruding into the sea: headland (the tip of the land protruding into the sea).
cape
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[①]［jiǎ］
["Jiyun" ancient 狎cut, enter 狎, see. ]
(1) Between the two mountains. Also called Gap.
(2) See "Headland".
(3) See "Jekou".
cape
English translation of words
◎ Cape
cape, headland, promontory
cape
Kangxi dictionary interpretation of words
[Yin Collection] [Mountain Character Department] 　 Cape; Kangxi Strokes: 8; Page Number: Page 309 Page 23
[Jiyun] Ancient Qiqie, sound A. By the side of the mountain. [Huainanzi·Yuan Daoxun] Wandering beside the cape. [Note] Cape, Yamawaki also. [Zuo Si·Wu Du Fu] Pour to the point of thinness, to the point of view. [Note] The two mountains are freely called Cape.　You Chi Cape, the name of the mountain, in the north of Shukui prefecture, there is a lonely city, Yuguyufu County base, south to Baidi Mountain, no vegetation, soil and rock are all red. The vulgar cloud is like a man's scapula, hence the name Chijia.　 Another cape, one after another. [Zhang Xie·Luo Yu Fu] All females, Yi Yi Qi Qi. The car rides on the promontory, overflowing with Zhongkui.　【Jiyun】or make?.

Old glyph
cape
Name meaning
Refers to the land that protrudes into the sea.
jiǎ
сущ.
1) подошва горы; долина (между двух гор)
岬岬 грот в горе; пещера в скалах
2) гористый мыс; береговой утёс
3) анат. мыс (выступ в барабанной полости среднего уха) (лат. promontorium)
Radicals: 山, 甲  (mountain, turtle-shell)
Meaning Mnemonic
You see a mountain in the shape of a turtle shell sticking out into the ocean. It's a cape! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
Reading Mnemonic
You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).
The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.
